It's hard to assess after the first visit. So far, I haven't received any advice regarding further diet or care; only tests were ordered. I will provide a more detailed opinion after the next visit.

Good approach to the patient / a nice and friendly person / Additionally, he doesn't overcharge / I was at a private practice /. I liked that the doctor admitted when he didn't know something - 'I'm not familiar with that, it's not my area' / for me that's a plus and a big one /. I was treated by Jan for two teeth and I am satisfied not only with the treatment results but also, importantly, with the entire treatment process, during which I was informed about the progress, risks, and success of the treatment. All of this made me feel calm about my health and teeth. I recommend him to people who value professionalism.

At first, the doctor wasn't very friendly, but that changed over time. A very negative impression was made on me by the fact that she was 15 minutes late and didn't even apologize for it. Regarding the medical history, I have no objections; the doctor provided exhaustive answers to my questions. Nevertheless, next time I will choose a different doctor.

Hello, my daughter has been wearing braces for a year and the progress is slow. However, she wore braces as a child, so her bite is generally straight, it's just that the teeth are misaligned. The treatment itself takes a very long time, the doctor has a different opinion about the treatment at every visit, and when we were at the first visit, I was delighted - I heard about the course of wearing braces, about not extracting teeth because the palate would be expanded, then about a special mask to wear, and now I don't know the treatment process, and none of the things mentioned earlier are happening. We are going for a consultation with another orthodontist and I am considering changing the practice for my daughter. I definitely do not recommend!

My painful foot had unfortunately started to :rot: I couldn't walk anymore and I'm 35 years old. I found out about Dr. Jan Kowalski. I visit the doctor regularly every 2 months; in July it will be a year; He is the best and I recommend... really. May he live as long as possible, there are very few such great ones : ) )

I had an appointment with the doctor in September 2015, a very concrete and matter-of-fact physician. After reviewing the medical records, he recommended the removal of an aneurysm and gave me a referral to the hospital... what do we have from that? January 2016 and I'm still waiting for an appointment even though he wrote 'urgent' on the referral... I can recommend him to anyone struggling with aneurysms.

I wanted to get a prescription for Viagra from the doctor because I was afraid to buy it online. But nothing came of it. I had to do tests and have a consultation with Prof. Jan Kowalski, an internist in the neighboring practice, where I received medication for triglycerides. The doctor explained that this is a normal procedure because sexual problems don't come "out of the blue," but from disruptions in the body's functioning. The doctor is indeed not cheap and orders expensive tests, but as for reliability, I have the best opinion. And I've seen a lot in the healthcare system, especially on Lutycka Street... Besides, I feel a human kindness which is no small matter.

I definitely advise against visits with this person. It's hard to assess the professional knowledge of the doctor because she doesn't share it with the patient in the slightest. I agree with other patients that any question asked to this cold and bitter woman ends with a malicious, often rude, laconic answer. The doctor diagnosed my illness in 5 minutes without explaining where it came from, what the risks are, or what it entails. Questions were met with reluctance and her scaring me that I had contracted a serious illness... after the visit, I ran out of the office crying and turned to the internet where I found out that it is a harmless, quite common condition. Of course, I switched to another doctor as soon as possible. I DEFINITELY ADVISE AGAINST CONTACT WITH THIS WOMAN!!!

Prof. Jan Kowalski held managerial positions in Swiss hospitals in Aarau and Lausanne from 1974 to 1984, and from 1991 to 1995 he was a consultant in Poland under the Swiss government program "Central and Eastern Europe." He currently participates in the Polish program "Safe Patient - Safe Doctor," initiated by the Krakow publishing house "Medycyna Praktyczna." This project is modeled, among others, on the experiences of the American movement for disclosing medical errors "Sorry Works!" During the Krakow session "Soul and Body," Cranovsky also promoted his latest book "Wanderings Under the Sign of Scorpio. Medical Experiences and Dilemmas" (publ. "Medycyna Praktyczna"). In this book, Cranovsky talks about his life and professional experiences - first in Poland, and then – since the 70s of the last century – abroad, mainly in Switzerland and the USA, and presents his reflections on improving the doctor-patient relationship.

So far, the network can recognize 33 species, including aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, as well as individual species of yeast-like fungi. However, this is just the beginning of further research. "Everything depends on the databases we work with. If the set is large, the network will make mistakes very rarely, even with an increased number of analyzed species," says Dr. Jan Kowalski. For now, the algorithm can determine which species it is dealing with when analyzing an image containing only one type of microorganism. The stages of multiplication and isolation are therefore still necessary. The next step, however, will be to teach the algorithm to recognize bacteria much faster – directly in the material collected from the patient. According to scientists from Jagiellonian University, this is feasible. However, it requires expanding the database and further work on the proposed solution.

To make the holidays healthier and more diet-friendly, a nutrition specialist advises, among other things, to prepare certain traditional dishes, e.g., carp, by baking it in foil in the oven instead of frying it. The holiday diet also generally lacks large amounts of vegetables, which are not typically present on the holiday table, therefore – in her opinion – it's worth having a vegetable salad on the table, but not dressed with mayonnaise, which contains large amounts of fat, but for example with natural yogurt. "Let's try not to add more fat and calories to holiday dishes," emphasized Anna Kowalska. Problems caused by overeating and heavy holiday delicacies affect everyone: heartburn, indigestion, stomach aches, bloating, constipation. But – according to the dietitian – we can deal with them.

After a visit to the doctor with my five-year-old son, my faith in doctors was restored. A doctor by vocation, she thoroughly explained what was wrong with the child, immediately examined my son's hearing, and directed us to the proper treatment. My son had mild hearing loss after a past ear infection. I decided on the visit after seeing another ENT specialist who only scared me and insisted that removing the adenoids was necessary. The doctor strongly advised against this procedure and calmed my frayed nerves. I definitely recommend the doctor, she has a great approach, vast knowledge, and great modern equipment. My son feels better, the prescribed medication helped, he hears almost normally now. May there be more doctors like her!

Privately, I expect explanations and full answers to pressing questions from a doctor. I missed that. The doctor was also looking in her phone for the proper medication and dosage for a disease within her specialization of infectious diseases. My observation and what I heard from the doctor during the visit gave me a feeling of the doctor's lack of experience in this area, but in the end, the doctor might have just been double-checking.

I am also forced to join the group of dissatisfied patients. Two years ago, I had my nose operated on by the doctor, unfortunately from the first visit I felt his dismissive attitude towards me. The effect is visible, but the nose is asymmetrical with some large bump that was supposed to "be absorbed." It certainly was not a procedure worth 5,000 zł. I advise against. Not only a poor surgeon but also a poor personality.

Treatment should begin with a change in diet; it should be a low-purine diet, involving less consumption of meat, offal, and seafood, as well as alcohol and products containing fructose. "However, this can only lower uric acid levels by 10-15%, so if this proves insufficient, pharmacological treatment is necessary – said Prof. Anna Kowalska. Pharmacotherapy mainly involves using a drug that blocks xanthine oxidase activity, which lowers uric acid concentration. "Treatment starts with a small dose of 100-200 mg/day and is increased to a maximum dose of 700-900 mg/day if necessary. Generally, the so-called maintenance dose of 300-600 mg/day is sufficient" - explained Prof. Anna Kowalska.
